awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multilevel Methods for Optimal Control of Partial Differential Equations and Optimization-Based Domain Decomposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Optimal control of differential equations (PDECO) plays an important role in an ever increasing number of real-life applications ranging from petroleum reservoir modeling to weather prediction and the optimal shape design of airplane wings. While traditional PDECO uses deterministic models, this project targets PDECO where the differential equations also include uncertainties, such as irregular fluctuations in the ground composition, or turbulent wind speeds. The ultimate aim is to dramatically improve the solution quality and the computing time of such optimal control problems. The novel algorithms resulted from this project will impact optimization problems arising in geophysics, weather modeling etc. These problems are generic and advances in solution techniques will also benefit other sciences. Open source software will be created and shared with the community. Four graduate students will benefit from the project. Special attention will be given to recruit students from underrepresented groups. 

The project is focused on developing robust, scalable multilevel solvers for mainly two classes of potentially large-scale PDECO problems: PDECOs constrained by stochastic partial differential equations (PDEs) and by nonlocal PDEs. An additional thrust is to develop multilevel solvers in support of optimization-based domain decomposition - another kind of PDECO - for the forward PDE-models themselves. Multilevel/multigrid solvers are known to be optimal for many classes of forward models. However, their application to solve PDECO problems is still in its infancy. A naive application of multilevel methods to solve such optimization problems can lead to dependence on resolution (mesh-dependence) and on other parameters of the problem such as the stochastic dimension or the number of subdomains. In addition, since each iterate involves at least one PDE solve, the cost of solving such optimization problems can be prohibitive for large-scale, high-resolution problems, especially for problems that are significantly more expensive than the traditional, deterministic ones. The algorithms developed in this project aim to set new standards of efficiency and robustness.  Novel mathematical tools will further advance the knowledge in numerical analysis and optimization. New special topics courses will be developed based on the research generated in the project and the notes will be shared with the community. The results of the research will be actively disseminated via technical research papers and talks at national and international conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This was a collaborative project between University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC) and George Mason University (GMU). The goal of the project was to design efficient solvers for optimization problems constrained by physical laws represented by partial differential equations (PDEs). Multilevel/multigrid solvers are known to be optimal for many classes of forward models. However, their application for solving optimization problems constrained by PDEs is still in its infancy. A naive application of multilevel methods to these constrained optimization problems can lead to mesh-dependence, i.e., the number of optimization iterations increases as the mesh is refined. Since each iterate involves at least one PDE solve, the cost of these problems can be prohibitive for large-scale, high-resolution problems, especially for non-local and stochastic PDE-models, which are significantly more expensive to solve than traditional PDEs. 
 
The following main tasks were undertaken by the GMU team. 1) Design and analysis of multi-level methods for optimization problems constrained by elliptic nonlocal / fractional PDEs. 2) Design and analysis of numerical methods for generic nonsmooth optimization problems. 3) Design and analysis of algorithms for bilevel optimization problems. 4) Training of Ph.D. students. 

Intellectual merit: Efficient multilevel methods for optimization problems constrained by fractional PDEs were created. These methods exhibit a high degree of robustness with respect to the fractional power and nonlocality. Optimization based-reduced order models were developed. These approaches are applicable to both traditional PDEs and nonlocal / fractional PDEs. A unified framework on optimization of nonlinear fractional PDEs was created. The proposed bilevel optimization based framework, where fractional operators are used are regularizers, is leading to new mathematical analysis. 
Broader impact: Novel, robust and efficient multilevel algorithms for fractional PDEs is leading to new research directions. Bilevel optimization framework is already being used extensively by the imaging and machine learning communities. The analytical results on nonsmooth nonconvex optimization problems is paving the way to design state-of-the-art algorithms in infinite dimensions. Multiple applications in materials science, imaging, fluid dynamics, shape optimization, neuromorphic imaging, are being directly impacted by the project. 
During the proposal period, the PI organized multiple minisymposia at national and international conferences. In addition, the PI organized 8 major conferences and summer schools. The PI and his graduate students gave more than 50 talks, including multiple keynote and plenary talks. The PI created one special topics course at graduate level. The project resulted in 25 publications, three Ph.D. dissertations. Also, 4 summer Ph.D. students and 1 undergraduate student were supported under the project. Two postdocs also contributed to the project.
